plants.name: Rosa spp.
plants.description: Roses are iconic flowering shrubs known for their fragrant, layered petals and wide variety of colors. Many species and cultivars reach peak bloom in early summer in temperate zones.
plants.location: Temperate regions worldwide, including North America, Europe, and Asia
plants.funFact: Roses are one of the oldest cultivated flowers, with fossils dating back 35 million years.

plants.name: Lupinus polyphyllus
plants.description: Lupines are tall spikes of pea-like flowers often found in wild meadows and gardens. They fix nitrogen in soil, improving fertility.
plants.bloomingSeason: Late spring through early summer (May to July)
plants.location: Native to western North America; widely cultivated in temperate climates
plants.funFact: Lupines can improve poor soils by fixing atmospheric nitrogen through root nodules.

plants.name: Hibiscus rosa-sinensis
plants.description: A tropical shrub bearing large, showy, trumpet-shaped flowers. In warm climates, it blooms throughout summer and sometimes year-round.
plants.bloomingSeason: Summer to fall; can be year-round in tropical climates
plants.funFact: Some cultures use hibiscus flowers to make herbal teas believed to have health benefits.

plants.name: Protea cynaroides
plants.description: The national flower of South Africa, this striking plant has large, spiky flower heads with a central dome surrounded by colorful bracts.
plants.bloomingSeason: Winter to summer (varies by region â€“ often blooming July in Southern Hemisphere)
plants.funFact: Proteas are ancient plants dating back over 300 million years, predating the dinosaurs.
